title: Morris-Taney-class cutter
text:
The "Morris"-"Taney"-class revenue cutters were 13 <a href="Cutter%20%28ship%29">cutters</a> built at <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> at the Webb and Allen shipyard between 18301833. These cutters were the backbone of the <a href="United%20States%20Revenue%20Cutter%20Service">United States Revenue Cutter Service</a> for more than a decade. <a href="Samuel%20Humphreys">Samuel Humphreys</a> designed these cutters for roles as diverse as fighting <a href="Piracy">pirates</a>, <a href="privateer">privateer</a>s, combating smugglers and operating with naval forces. He designed the vessels on a naval <a href="schooner">schooner</a> concept. They had <a href="Baltimore%20Clipper">Baltimore Clipper</a> lines. The vessels, built by Webb and Allen, were designed by Isaac Webb and resembled Humphreys' design but had one less port.
According to <a href="William%20Thiessen">William Thiessen</a>, this was the first class of cutters where all ships were identical.
References.
